headline: Production Mechanic
pros: Decent pay, good benefits and nice coworkers
cons:
Don't walk, run from this job, you'll hate every second of it.  No work life balance, forced overtime during the weeks and almost every weekend.  (was told I would work Mon-Fri that didn't happen)  They try to run around the clock with very little resources so the resources they do have are very overworked and stressed to the max.  Then when you do get forced you usually end up sitting around waiting for all the managers from all different departments try to make a decision what to do next and not one of them wants to make a decision in fear of a higher boss not liking that decision made.  Always wait till the last second to announce overtime so you cant plan anything.  Only for sure way to get time off is to use a benefit.  
Very slow to provide resources as promised in the contract if they provide them at all.  If you don't park the way they want you to you'll get written up by one of their security super troopers.
Don't really get to use much maintenance skill here most of the real maintenance work is contracted out.  They will put you through school but you wont get to use anything you learn because Pfizer doesn't want the liability.  Don't think the place will make it another 5 years the way its being run.

headline: Constantly Changing Directions
pros: Great at recruiting talent but struggles to maintain talent
cons: Senior management not held accountable so it is hard to keep talent because employees don't leave a company, they leave difficult managers.

headline: Senior Director
pros: Quality of colleagues overall is good, particularly those that are individual contributors.  They work hard and are very conscientious.  There is good cross functional collaboration around projects.  The company is large and because of its size can leverage for access to a wide array of resources that may not be available at small companies.
cons:
Pfizer was once a great place to work, however, today in order to make Wall Street's number the company is too focused on short term gains that are gotten by cutting and squeezing efficiencies out of programs.  Five years ago there was quite a bit of "fat" that could be trimmed, however today the programs are so lean that they really do not even have the minimum amount of resources needed to be successful.  The cuts are beginning to run so deep that serious mistakes are being made that I am afraid may lead to safety issues.

In addition Pfizer is also having a cultural crisis.  They have implemented two policies called Own It and Straight Talk, which on their surface sound great.  However, in reality the corporate culture is still to do things as they have always been done.  The company is closed minded to innovative ways of doing things and many in management only want people who say yes to anything, not employees who are trying to make the best decisions for patients, the company and shareholders.  Unfortunately it is a "what is in it for me only" mentality.   I am less than bullish on the company prospects as the company continues to shrink and not invest in new assets.

headline: good

headline: Great salary and benefits but poor decision making
pros: Salary and benefits are great and the vast majority of colleagues are nice people and great at their jobs.
cons: Reliance on acquisitions and organizational instability perpetuate poor R&D productivity. Nepotism and upward management and politics drive poor decision-making. Too many people with shallow knowledge of project specifics involved in decision making. OWN-IT cultural initiative borders on Thought Police at times - lip-service in public, but I have never had a private conversation with any colleague who thought it was useful for every single colleague to spend a day away from work at a stage-managed OWN-IT day. Like all big companies, prioritization of portfolio is a preoccupation, fear of investing in the wrong thing and burdensome governance slow down the process, damaging competitive edge and requiring in-licensing to fuel portfolio, often not scrutinized thoroughly enough. Deals done for the wrong reasons, (especially to meet annual goals).

headline: Short Sighted Vision
pros:
Excellent work place
Flexible work hours
Used to have a great pension plan
cons: Very business oriented vision, which have nothing to do with science. Their goal is always and have been to acquire small or big companies. Take over their pipeline and market it to the advantage of thier shareholders. At the end, employees are the biggest losers. Their bonus is meant to be for their executive management, which once again, have nothing to do with science but planning and implementing mergers and acquisitions. In the long run, this company will not survive in medicine business because company is being run by finance executives.  Case in point, Pfizer tried to take over AstraZeneca.

headline: Director
pros: Flexible work from home schedule
cons: Disconnect between rewarding performance (defined as OWN IT) and actual compensation.  Their compensation philosophy is to bring people on below the mid-point in the salary grade, and pay no more than the mid-point.  They define the 50 percentile (compared to benchmarked companies) as competitive.  This seems fundamentally flawed as other companies are paying more for top talent in the same position (I have been a top performer every year I have worked there).  Management lacks the will to differentiate performance.  Expect an annual 1-3% merit increase with bonus payout no higher than 130%.

headline: Good Company to work for
pros:
Of course is not the same as some years ago, but still is a nice company to work for.

Experience: you will experience a lot of good challenges, projects, the opportunity to visit other countries, to have assignments in other areas, to deal and share with top and tough professionals.  Is a great culture!

Flex Time: you can choose your schedule, you can work from home one day per week, on Fridays you work until 1pm, free extra days at the holiday season (dec - jan), if you for some reason needs to get out earlier or arrive late you just talk with you manager.

IT Dptment: great tools and connectivity to work from home.  If you received an iPhone things are very easy.  In my role you almost can work from home everyday.  Virtual meetings.

People:  very professional, multicultural, respect for diversity.
cons:
Professional Development or Promotions: if you work for the Bussiness you will have several opportunities to growth.  However if you work for an enabling functions as IT, HR, Finance, Legal and others it will be very difficult to get a promotion...you will need to wait, sometimes several years.

Lack of training for the enabling functions.  But it's understandable because of the budget restrictions.  Even though the company has online courses as HMM, SkillsSoft, and others.

Retention of Talent: in some cases is almost impossible that you receive a counteroffer is like a rule, if you want to go then go.

headline: Global Financial Services "GFS" environment with SAP ERP
pros:
If you a talented financial person and can operate effectively in high stress environment this is for you.  This is an opportunity to show that you are innovative and knowledgeable, and you will leapfrog over the many staff accountants (CPS's).     
There is opportunity to get involved on one of the many acquisitions (integration projects), divestitures or re-organization projects at Pfizer.  There are many permanent and temporary assignments with the opportunity to relocate across the globe for this fortune 100 company.
cons: The shared services organization is always subject to down sizing and other cost cutting measures as Pfizer continues to open "Off-Shore" Shared Services organizations (Poland, China, India, Costa Rica,..) and the "Lift and Shift" policy of resources is reinforced daily.  If you are the coming into this organization just be warned that the Shared Services group does not develop their people. and do not value experienced professionals.   The technology is always 5 to 10 years behind standard business practices  (MS-Office, In 2014, moved off Windows XP).   "GFS" Leadership frequently changes and each leader has to place their own "thumbprint" on the organization, which basically, means throwing a wrench into the works to influence talented employees to leave the organization.

Low salary

headline: Dramatic change
pros: Never got bored, learn to be self dependent, well trained (in the past particularly), benefits as vacations plan.  Good reputation in the market. You will have so many skills that you can fit perfectly in every company you wish, and the workload never be as much as in this company.
cons: You will be solving everything by your own.  Too focus on results, numbers but people. It takes to much time to be promoted, they don¬¥t want to change you from your position if your good on what you do, they prefer to hired someone who doesn¬¥t know us internally, and after seeing how its mess up ended leaving the company, and maybe at that time you will be promoted.

headline: Impeccable training and leadership
pros: Talented, innovative group of self-directed individuals who are always willing to help one another. This allows continuous opportunity to learn and grow. Great compensation. Investment in the best training out there, which is why Pfizer is known for having the best representatives.
cons: The climate of the pharmaceutical industry has changed over the years, with layoffs always looming. It used to be that the majority of employees stayed with the company over 20 years. Now staying for at least 10 years is rare. Not a lot of opportunity to advance in other departments if you start out in the sales division.

headline: pfizer purchaser
pros: manage supplier, make purchase order
cons: no much training, but the job is challenging

headline: Great experience
pros: Great training, Great people, job as tough or easy as you want it to be.  Need stellar relationships and the right territory with managed care wins to make it to president's club.
cons: none, great company.

headline: Very good company
pros: Work with High quality people
cons: The outlook for the current portfolio - Stability?

headline: Pharma networking at its best
pros: Great start to the industry; training is solid, can learn the pharma business and earn a reputation with physicians in designated territory; Support from direct manager can amplify or stifle your ability to sell into the market.
cons: Work schedules and expectations are intense. Many after hours activities and programs required to access target physicians.

headline: Great company
pros: Money, People, benefits, all great.  Challenging workplace, lots of opportunties.  YOu get to learn a lot about pharmaceuticals their manufacturing and sales.
cons: Older colleague demographic, long hours, challenging work with little performance based compensation

headline: 30 years with Pfizer
pros: Pfizer is a Fortune 50 company and industry leader with global operations and the resources to train and equip their personnel to the highest standards. In 30 years with the company, I learned an enormous amount about healthcare, disease management, business management, leadership, advocacy, communication and so much more. Their compensation and opportunities for personal and professional development were outstanding. Even though I was 'downsized' after 30 years, I cannot harbor contempt for a company that taught me so much and enriched my life tremendously.
cons: Despite the many Pros of a career with Pfizer, I can only rate the organization with 3 of 5 stars because during my later years, as the company expanded greatly and acquired numerous other companies, I was increasingly surrounded with colleagues who lacked the professional standards that Pfizer taught me in my early years. Leaders at the highest level of the corporation created an atmosphere of distrust and a sense that the company was 'circling the drain'. While patent expirations, pressures from managed care, negative public opinion of the industry and gaps in scientific discovery were putting substantial pressure on the company, fewer and fewer of the leaders seemed able to provide calm guidance and honest leadership but instead, seemed to panic.

headline: Great opportunity to start your career in pharma, not so good when you grow over the starting level
pros: The company offers very good work/life balance, salary, and severance package, which is important (see cons);  the colleagues are knowledgeable and good overall.
cons: There are very limited opportunities for the career growth. Frequent layoffs that target research positions much more than the management ones. This results in low morale. The mid-senior and the higher level management is a weak aspect of Pfizer as very few are true leaders and the rest are playing games.

headline: Good company but difficult to move up. Career growth is very challenging
pros: good company in terms of work/family balance. Flexible working from home policy
cons: Poor career growth opportunity. Difficult to get things done.

headline: Great people, rewarding work.
pros: Awesome facilities, helpful co workers,
cons: Relatively low pay for interns

headline: Pfizer has no concern about it's employees or it's products.
pros: Lots of overtime.  Have met some great coworkers who really care about our patients and their wellbeing.   Some really inspirational people who do excellent work despite corporate's complete apathy for us and our products.
cons: Very toxic work environment, some of the worst management I have ever seen.   Moral is very low, high stress and constant tension causing a lot of issues with bullying or lack of professionalism.  Draconian budget cuts leading the "leaner" workforce to crumple under combined work loads.  Constantly lacking the tools to do your job adds to the pressure.  Supervision responds to concerns by telling you your job could easily go to Mexico.  Pressure to cut corners compromise the overall product quality.  This feels like a company on the verge of catastrophe.   Most of the blue collar work force is made up of temporary workers with low pay and no benefits hanging on for years hopeing to be hired in.  Super high turn over rates mean constant training, total lack of experience, new workers training newer workers.   Management happy to reassure you that your totally replaceable.  I could go on and write pages and pages.

headline: Pfizer Review
pros: Summer hours allow early departure on Fridays during summer.
cons: Leadership is lacking.  The environment makes it very difficult to get things done.

headline: Smart, nice people, interesting work
pros: The people are very smart and nice. You learn a lot from everyone you work with and you improve as a result of being around such talented people. The work is interesting and there are opportunities to get involved with diverse projects.
cons: You can get stuck at one level for a long time and it can be difficult to advance. You would likely have to apply for a new job in a different group to get a promotion.

headline: Project Manager
pros: Great Benefits, Flex Hours working remotely few days a week. Majority of Folks Friendly and Hard-working.
cons: International Travel, High pressure job with tight deadlines. Seems to now be in a constant down-sizing mode, Some unreasonable cost cutting affecting long-term employees.

headline: Senior scientist
pros:
Big company
Chance to learn more
Value science
Treats employees good
Otgaanized
cons:
They don't do h1
They don't have recruiters
They don't have pod holidays

headline: Constant reorgs, mergers, and organizational disruptions.
pros: Good camaraderie, investment in people, areas of excellence
cons: Political, challenging career advancement, ax is always out.  Had seven managers in six years, acquisitions and divestitures are a constant source of distraction and uncertainty.

headline: Good, but lot of Redtape
pros: Flexible work schedule.  Lots of opportunities to learn new things.
cons: Depending on the department Work Life /balance is gone.

headline: Terrible. Treated contract employees very poorly.
pros: The work done wasn't particularly challenging. Management was cordial (if unresponsive to concerns). Work environment was generally clean.
cons: Almost no chance of moving up. Work environment was mind numbingly boring. The only people who stayed long-term were those who couldn't do anything else.

headline: What I expect from corporate America
pros: Will hire people with no work experience or non-relevant work experience.
cons: Poor compensation, long hours, little room for growth, no promotions.

headline: Associate
pros:
Benefits
Culture 
Work Life Balance 
Vacation
On site Dr 
On site gym
cons:
No promotions 
Favoritism 
Same people are often given promotions

headline: Career Disaster - Please stay away!
pros: Relatively competitive salary + benefits
cons: No training, high complacency, very negative mindset of colleagues, most capable people have either left or been fired, most employees in higher age bracket and only looking forward to their retirement and benefits. Younger lot strongly discouraged from thinking different.

headline: Depressing culture, everyone just going through the motions
pros: Pay is good but only if you get overtime.  Benefits are generous.
cons: Lots of disgruntled people with poor outlooks on life.  People know that they are stuck in this job for life because no one else in the area pays as well.  If you make waves, management will mess with you so it's best to just keep quiet and don't report anything you see.  People will not follow SOP and will intentionally cut corners at the risk of product safety.  Lots of theft throughout the plant in Kalamazoo.  Lock up your belongings.

headline: The commitment toward's the company has ruined our career
pros: Fortunate to have worked for Pfizer for long long time got us momentary recognition but ruined our careers
cons: keep watching who is at the helm, learn to buttress. If u r a committed person but don't know how to dramatize then you will remain a daudtha huaa goda with the carrot of promotion in front......

headline: The Consumer division is a mess
pros: Work from home flexibility, half day fridays.
cons: Poor management.  Future of the consumer division is unclear.

headline: One of the best companies to work for
pros: Training and development, bonuses, competitive salary
cons: Pressing the limits with quota

headline: Average Company
pros: The benefits are consistent with industry standards.
cons: Lacks the collaborative environment and training for certain roles are not supportive enough.  People do not feel empowered to speak up.

headline: good and bad
pros: great salary, great coworkers. Benefits are great.
cons: job security, layoffs all the time.

headline: ehhhhh
pros: Relaxed environment most of the time, sneak in youtube here or there, team work sometimes
cons: Too dependant on low paid contractors, to get into the locations is now a pain

headline: It all depends on the manager you have.
pros: Competitive Salary, health benefits, given more vacation the longer you stay with the company.  Opportunity to do secondments in other departments (if your manager approves)
cons: Colleagues are let go often, the usual unstable pharmaceutical business issues. Depending on your level 15-20% of your salary is held back and if you perform well it's given to you as a "bonus".  However, if you do well, and the company performs well then you get your % plus a little extra.

headline: Excelent
pros: The first one is the great organizational climate. You also have a lot of opportunities to grow. And it is one of the most ethical companies
cons: The work-life balance is a myth here. The processes are very buroucratic so it is Hard to do things. Salaries are not the Best

headline: Great start of a career and wonderful experience
pros: I enjoyed the training they provided! They really know how to train sales representatives in what they will experience in the field. I was able to take what I learned with the many years of experience and apply the medical knowledge in many other aspects of my career and life. The managers I had were great, as well as many of the regional managers, and treated me with professional respect. I know I was very lucky in having that common professionalism throughout those many years!
cons: Unfortunately, like with many other companies within this industry, there has been a loss of focus at corporate the past ten years. Many promising medications not making to market, constant mergers looking for R&D growth with no blockbusters to show, and no direction from a company standpoint.

headline: Great benefits but lacks good moral
pros:
salaries are great when compared to other companies
benefits i.e maternity, sick leave, paid vacation days are great. 
Access to technology for research is good and get to learn a lot of different techniques
cons:
lay offs happen too often..almost every year.
departments don't last for too long

headline: Love it
pros: nice people, nice office, nice location
cons: low salary, horrible boss, lack of strategy

headline: Good career growth opportunity
pros: Pfizer provided excellent opportunities for personal and professional development.
cons: It can be difficult to get things done at Pfizer. Lots of bureaucratic processes.

headline: no one is home
pros: you will have many, many colleagues
cons: none of which will have anything to do with you once you get downsized

headline: A great place to work.
pros: Work life balance and work style flexibility are strong attributes supporting the companies culture. I able to challenge myself in safe environments  while exploring many avenues of opportunity working the others on a global scale.
cons: A very large engine with many hoops to jump through to get things done.  Senior management is attempting to fix this issue.

headline: We were bought-out by Pfizer.
pros: They have a great deal of money and resources.
cons: Retaining the positive culture of our company was impossible after the buy-out.

headline: Aggressive company, but with opportunities
pros: Broad opportunities to learn new areas and skills, and a willingness to give people the opportunity to do so.
cons: As with any large company, strategic decisions can result in significant closures and layoffs, making one feel like a number, not a colleague.  And Pfizer is known for their acquire and reduce strategy for growth.  On the flip side, severance is fair.

headline: currently going through issues at Meridian-St. Louis site
pros: compensation is good, benefits are very good, health care inexpensive.  they are improving processes....however...
cons: still going thru issues with incorporation of various systems, and trying to do too much at one time.  its turned cut-throat, environment is not pleasant like it had been, stressful, alot of internal change of leadership.

headline: currently going through issues at Meridian-St. Louis site
pros: compensation is good, benefits are very good, health care inexpensive.  they are improving processes....however...
cons: still going thru issues with incorporation of various systems, and trying to do too much at one time.  its turned cut-throat, environment is not pleasant like it had been, stressful, alot of internal change of leadership.

headline: Great company in which to build and develop a career
pros: Great training, good salaries, great benefits, friendly people, and opportunities for advancement
cons: Company became more bureaucratic and political as time went on and massive layoffs were implemented

headline: Supply Chain Internship
pros: Great environment, real work, treated like an employee
cons: I have no cons for this company

headline: Good place to work  but lacks work-life balance
pros: There are many opportunities to grow within the company not only locally but also internationally. Provides a competitive salary and benefits in Mexico.
cons: Work-life balance is hard.  There is a lot of pressure to do things quickly but the processes are very bureaucratic. The working environment is tough due to the pressure among the different departments.

headline: Very Challenging
pros: No Promotions, opportunities to seek training in whatever you want. Good educational reimbursement plan
cons: Culture is very hierarchical. hard work is not always rewarded

headline: It's been great, very diverse company and always bringing in minorities.
pros: The company is very diverse which is great. Benefits are great but not as good as they have been in the past. The management is great and very humble. No problems so far. 3 weeks of vacation is great as well
cons: Learning everything and all of the equipment is very complex. I haven't been there long enough to have anything.negative come across to me. Pay is not that competitive although competitive.

headline: Good Job
pros: This job provides good pay and benefits
cons: Their is long work hours and shift work

headline: Nice people, stagnant environment.
pros: Innovative minds that can develop skillset
cons: leadership, troubleshooting, accounting for every individuals voice.

headline: Pretty happy so far
pros: Excellent working environment; friendly, educated and engaged colleagues; great benefits and perks; lots of flexibility and lateral movement options; a lot of time and energy goes into developing the culture, embracing diversity, and creating an OWN IT! attitude
cons: Many people in my role seem to stay in this type of position for a significant amount of time (7-25 years).  This is definitely not something of interest to me and many Gen X/Y'ers.

headline: It is an excellent company with high competitiveness.
pros:
As long as you do your job, nobody questions the time you come in and leave the office.
Your work is appreciated.
People are helpful.
cons:
Communication between departments can be an issue sometimes.
Competitiveness is high.

headline: Liked the people for the most part, but the workplace was dysfunctional.
pros: Knowledgeable people who are passionate about their work and the benefits that the products they work on provide to patients.
cons: People are constantly being pulled in so many different directions that they cannot focus on what they need to focus on in order to do a good job and get their real work done.

headline: Pfizer is a well oiled, big pharma machine.
pros: Great benefits, lots of perks, free car with insurance and gas.
cons: Mediocre pay, very conservative culture, fairly high level of micromanagement.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Lovely staff and management who care about work/life balance, generous employee benefits and perks, positive workplace culture
cons: Large multinational, difficult to progress as an employee

headline: I worked at Pfizer for 9 years in Human Resources and it was a great experience in the Pharmaceutical Division
pros: I had a great experience and till this day use many of my learnings in all that I do.
cons: I had no challenges; mobility and career growth was always available. Transitioning from manufacturing to marketing was very easy.

headline: Great Place to work
pros: They do good science and have lots of money to throw at projects.
cons: Very big place, so it is easy to get lost.

headline: Great Company
pros: flexible work time, work from home available. Competitive salary and benefits. Great opportunity to move up within the organisation.
cons: when the rubber hits the road you definitely need to dig in and work hard but no more than any other company I have worked for.

headline: The "death spiral" continues with the only way to slow it down is to continue to cut costs, spin or acquire
pros: People are great - really caring and down to earth. Care about you as an individual
cons: Nothing much to do to grow or increase as its all about cutting and reducing or splitting up

headline: Finance & Business Operations Colleague
pros: Great organization to work for with excellent work/life balance. Organization has done a great deal of work in changing the overall culture to an Own It Culture that fosters innovation, collaboration, and respect. Management does a good job in being transparent and encouraging to its organization
cons: Things take FOREVER to get done, meaning type of projects have to go through numerous approvals that are sometimes unnecessary and inefficient.  Also, if you are looking for fast job advancement, this is not the place for you; if you are okay in being in the same role for 10 years, then you will be happy here.

headline: My experience in this company was very good, because they prepared me in every task that has to do with manufacturingbec
pros: Give you the opportunity to grow professionally and benefits.
cons: learn something new every day and  have the confidence that through the training you're doing well

headline: A good place to work .
pros: Provide innovative drugs that provide health solutions to difficult health problems.9
cons: Pay is at lower range of industry standard.

headline: A good place to work .
pros: Provide innovative drugs that provide health solutions to difficult health problems.9
cons: Pay is at lower range of industry standard.

headline: Educational
pros: Pfizer training was second to none.  I still use things today I learned there as a brand new representative.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy.   Not nimble to respond to market conditions.   I was definitely a "number."

headline: Ying and yang, depends upon manager.
pros: Decent benefits, nice severance package, nice campuses.
cons: Constant threat of job loss, depending upon your manager/department must be available via phone and computer to work after hours and on weekends. in short, they espouse work life balance but don't mean it. Overworked people hold up what you are on the line to complete leading to even more stress. Great place to learn how to stab people in the back, while appearing innocent, in order to keep your own job. Throwing people under the buss is an art form here.

headline: Nice people, great work life balance
pros: work life balance is very good
cons: Career opportunities, it can be difficult to progress

headline: Pizer Corporation
pros: As far as biotech goes, advanced. Especially computer systems, documentation, trending, and OE
cons: Felt like a big corporation. You are just another number.

headline: Just the numbers
pros: Really enjoyed my job prior to Pfizer's takeover.  I think I would have enjoyed working for Pfizer if I had been hired by them but my job was slated for going away when the company bought us.
cons: Relocation was not offered nor would it have worked for my family. I don't believe this is always the case.

headline: Director operations
pros: Global, talented people, nyc location
cons: Politics, greed, too large

headline: System Administrator
pros: Great working environment. Everyone is helpful.
cons: Difficult to become a full time Pfizer Employee.

headline: Stimulating, energetic, never a dull moment.
pros: Highly focused on innovation, attracting only the best in business and accordingly rewarding them
cons: Due to it's huge company size, a lot of time and efforts are spent on navigating the internal processes and procedures.

headline: Low wages
pros: Good vacation package compared to competition.
cons: Below average wages for non degree oriented workers.

headline: Just don't expect structured development
pros: Organized, powerful, large company with obvious breadth and clout in the pharmaceutical industry. It is a collection if too notch people but with no sense of how to build community and cultural cohesion. (See cons)
cons: They may talk about developing their people, but they haven't a clue what that really means.  Everyone's too preoccupied with being correct and appearing in control for their to be any humility and growth.

headline: I did my job, and they paid me - pretty well.
pros: Pay and benefits and the chance to work with a lot of really incredible people!
cons: Look out for yourself, as nobody else is going to..

headline: Low Morale
pros: Excellent people. Excellent resources. Good benefits (but are getting cut). Generally work/life balance is good.
cons: After a decade of constant layoffs, morale is terrible. You can feel like the axe can fall at any time. Pfizer is too quick to go to layoffs without assessing the portfolio needs a few years out. Too driven by accountants and the immediate financials instead of playing the long game. The delayering from a few years ago created very little room for moving up the corporate latter. The annual news is always to do more with fewer resources. In the almost decade of work, I never got anything more than a 3% annual pay raise despite always getting solid to excellent annual reviews.

headline: Don't work here
pros: Some managers are flexible. Pay is better than average, but it is the case of the golden handcuffs.
cons: No growth, constant lay offs, constant mergers, no work life balance.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Always new challenges & great colleagues to work with
cons: High demanding work place - the best of the best

headline: Great salary
pros: The best part of this job was the team I was on.  We were like a family.
cons: The only challenges I faced were pharmacy issues with generic substitution

headline: Great experience overall
pros: I learned alot from leadership, got my formal education paid (mostly) by the company.  I was promoted to various positions that continually expanded my skill sets.  Worked with great teams and really motivating, smart people!
cons: Unfortunately, when we changed a couple of CEOs, the company took a nose dive.  If the senior leaders in charge spoke to people that worked for them, alot of terrible company direction decisions could have be averted.

headline: Good company but not  iam going to retire here.
pros: Savings and flexible work life but always professional
cons: Will be let go in 8 years

headline: Network/system Engineer
pros: Good solid structure, very big company offices all over
cons: Mostly contract jobs, not easy to get in.

headline: coder
pros: great stuff good environment to work
cons: nothing was bad, great enviroment

headline: coder
pros: great stuff good environment to work
cons: nothing was bad, great enviroment

headline: Eye opening and very disappointing
pros:
Big name that looks good on your C.V. Very good training for new recruits and a robust online learning system.
Good products that are very competitive
cons: Global leadership is insensitive to the plight of workers in developing countries. A Pfizer representative has very poor working tools in developing countries and they are very poorly paid

headline: Good company to work for.
pros: Opportunities for advancement are there for anyone willing to do the work.
cons: Large companies have extra red tape and lengthy approval processes. Pfizer is no different. Sometimes there are non-value added approvals to slow things down.

headline: Pfizer global marketing
pros: Good compensation flexible work arrangements
cons: Constant Layoffs, poor and declining  morale

headline: Good Company But it Could Use Some Changes....
pros:
-Excellent Benefits
-Good Work Environment; Stable
-Company strives to achieve good work/home life balance (Three weeks vacation plus a week off in Dec. is very nice).
cons:
-It's difficult to change department, especially if you're in Manufacturing.
-Engineers appear to be favored over individuals with BS on Biology, Biochemistry ect.
-Raises are minimal . Promotions are a rarity.

headline: General Manager
pros: Benefits are good, salary is as well
cons: workers are layed off to quickly

headline: Too corporate.
pros: Big pharma generally means higher salaries
cons: Big pharma generally means lack of individual recognition

headline: good place to start career
pros: great work life balance, met many intelligent -hard working individuals, really enjoyed working with co-workers
cons: Big company- more focused on profits and less on people

headline: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times...
pros: In the beginning (~2000-2006), it was a fantastic place to work--for the most part, vibrant and intelligent co-workers and superiors, good company values and as an employee you felt part of something bigger and good.  Surprisingly good opportunities to expand your knowledge even in the most routine aspects of your role, great benefits, good compensation and a feeling of family.  After they started having you interview for your job, combining roles, and neglecting one of their core values "Respect For People", it all changed.  Motivation and morale dropped considerably, the average were rewarded while the outstanding were marginalized.
cons: Very little room for career advancement; too many 'old boys' club approaches to business and slightly arthritic in their adoption of technologies and process that would improve the organization.

headline: Innovative and fast moving for "Big Pharma"
pros:
Scale
Very professional work environment
Dedicated employees
Worthwhile mission
cons: Upheaval - non stop acquisitions and restructuring. Considerable layoffs

headline: Great Experience!
pros: Learned a lot and was allowed to be independent in the Lab.
cons: I have no cons when I interned at Pfizer.

headline: Marketing Director
pros: Terrific place to extend one's knowledge significantly. If you want to stay 'static' at your level you can....if you wish to keep growing, there are plenty of opportunities. Hard work and commitment is paid off. Some brilliant minds work here - LEARN from them. Salaries and benefits are great. The best supervisor in my entire career to date has been while at Pfizer. Energetic & high visibility ERG groups as well.
cons: Work-life balance can be challenging. Pfizer pays well...but expect you to work very hard.This will & can be a challenge. Can be a bit of a "big boy's club" at times. Gender imbalances at the top. Had one supervisor, fortunately the only one in my career to date, the used malicious and very underhand workplace bullying. Fortunately, I was able to move after 8 months but he was awful. Be aware it can happen anywhere. The pros at Pfizer, however, far outweighed the cons though!

headline: great
pros: work and life balance is good. flexible working time. no hurry for the work.
cons: no appreciation for assocaites senior manager cares more for their own benefits not for the junior assocaites.

headline: It was good ,up to a point...
pros: The salary is good, the benefits are decent, and the working conditions are good.  The working environment was good and it was really clean place to work.
cons: You were consistently dealing with low employee morale and poor quality employees on an almost daily basis.  You weren't always dealt with on an upfront basis and the company line wasn't followed at the site level all the time.

headline: Great company.  Salary not as competitive with other companies.
pros: Great work-life balance, benefits, and work environment
cons: Salary and bonus pay structure

headline: Great environment, if you can dodge the layoffs
pros: Great Salary, Room for advancement,
cons: Constant Downsizing, No Job security

headline: Ever changing
pros: Salary, benefits, people, the best equipment
cons: There were 3 major overhauls/layoffs in the 1 year I worked here. Too much time spent on meetings and not enough on the science

headline: Competitive
pros: There are a lot of very talented people in the organization to learn a lot from.  Summer Fridays are a plus too.
cons: Those very talented people can at times become a little too competitive which may may hinder progress.  Politics per usual.

headline: Pfizer Inern
pros: Very professional, great people to help grow my skills
cons: Company seems to cost cut too much when drugs go off patent

headline: Pfizer Consumer Healthcare
pros: Willing to partner with Retailers to drive category sales and share.  Looking for ways to improve retailer's market share in key categories.  Focused on building partnerships through driving shopper, category, and consumer insights.  Solid training and good benefits.
cons: Sometimes slow to act on Retailer's key initiatives and market trends to make changes to programs and product mix.  Tended to over-focus on a few customers vs. driving sales and share across all classes of trade.

headline: Scary
pros: Great pay.  Good people.  Interesting work.
cons: You never know when you might lose your job.  They are slowly taking away all of the benefits that would keep employees.  Too scary anymore.

headline: Hard work gets you no rewards
pros: competitive base pay, good medical benefits, unlimited sick time
cons: political, keeps low performers which brings down the morale, no bonus depending on level

headline: Great company
pros: wonderful opportunity to work with highly talented people,  terrific work environment, interesting projects, forward thinking (at least tend to be), very collaborative culture, good salary, great benifits,
cons: large organization, many proceses, lots of meetings,  very matrixed organization, not easy to navigate around, not agile enough to today's rapidly changing standards.

headline: Great Co benefits
pros: Great overall company benefits, pay and offers flexible work environment
cons: As financials or projects change you may be expected to relocate or be laid off.

headline: Excellent workplace
pros: Excellent workplace, culture, trainings, professionalism, opportunities, personal and professional balance, innovation, good benefits, excellent and challenging experiences.
cons: Although policies are required for a company's practice, this company has a lot of them to consider and keep in mind in daily operations and when making a decision.

headline: nerve-racking
pros: good benefits, good salary, good direct manager
cons: Pfizer purchased Wyeth and wiped out R&D

headline: Senior scientist
pros: Experienced team, great collaboration, get things done quickly when focused
cons: Reorganizations too frequent, lost continuity sometimes

headline: Cut cut cut
pros: Summer Fridays and flexible work schedules.  Good 401K match
cons: No organic growth.  Financial engineering is a must.  Cuts and stock buy back.

headline: great experience
pros:
great people 
Giant organization 
care about innovation
cons: needs to stabilize the business modle

headline: Great benefits, some great people, no job security
pros: I worked in a small division that had a great culture and everyone was very focused on the task at hand.  Great benefits and work/life balance and we had a lot of fun in the group I worked with, not common in the larger organization.  Benefits are great.
cons: Constant reorganizations and changing business plans create an environment where you never know what you will be doing 6 months/1 year from now.  Different divisions are very protective of there work so collaboration and communication is very difficult.

headline: Great place to work! I have the luck of only having great managers here.
pros: Good opportunities to develop the carrer.
cons: In contanst reorganization, which causes constant changes in projects.

headline: Great Place to work if you are a self starter
pros: Unlimited resources, good staff, competitive culture
cons: Large company dynamics and politics

headline: Continuous Restructuring
pros: People-oriented environment with lots of interdepartment collaborations.
cons: Continuous restructuring leads to sense of insecurity.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Good resources to use with customers, great internal teams
cons: Very flat organization, few opportunities for in-position advancement,

headline: Every year it got worse
pros: This company has no values
cons: Leadership is not to be trusted

headline: Working for a large, big pharma company has its advantages and disadvantages.
pros: Flexible work schedule, great benefits: health, life, car.  Great products with a solid pipeline of new products in the works.
cons: Huge company and it's easy for things to get lost in the shuffle.  The right hand doesn't seem to know what the left hand is doing. Management is often disconnected from reality and don't have perspective on the importance of interpersonal relationships.

headline: Experience with good research and great colleagues damaged by frequent restructuring, changing priorities and M&A .
pros: I was a scientist at the bench who found lots of challenge, personally fulfilling research and excellent resources (equipment budget, reagents) for work.  My immediate colleagues were great co-workers with a sense of team.
cons: Developing a product that requires several years to market is impossible with when reprioritizing, restructuring and site closures occur every six months.  There was churn in the personnel in upper management and there was lack of clarity of research goals in middle management.  There was little opportunity for career growth for scientists within the company.

headline: My department is fantastic; overall company leadership is uneven
pros: My department is fantastic... we do good science and we have the resources to do technology development at a level that I probably wouldn't have the opportunity to do at very many other companies.
cons: The company doesn't know what it wants to look like and this leads to zigging and zagging, inconsistent strategies, and disruptive reorganizations/relocations/etc.  Are we getting bigger doing a megamerger and trying to diversify?  Are we getting smaller by spinning off to become "focused" on our "core"?  Whatever it is this year, 1-2 years from now it will be an about face.

headline: very friendly company
pros: everyone is experienced, nice and helpful
cons: Boston is very expensive, so I don;t like the traffic and house price

headline: Great company to work in!
pros: Resources, opportunities for growth, very diverse, great health insurance, compensation is fair, the sky is the limit as far as what you can do- you have to know how to navigate this big organization though...
cons: As every big company, this one is not different. It's political, tough to navigate and slow to take decisions. Those who manage up- are usually rewarded by Senior. Management.

headline: Great company to work in!
pros: Resources, opportunities for growth, very diverse, great health insurance, compensation is fair, the sky is the limit as far as what you can do- you have to know how to navigate this big organization though...
cons: As every big company, this one is not different. It's political, tough to navigate and slow to take decisions. Those who manage up- are usually rewarded by Senior. Management.

headline: The business has just been through a period of massive changes and losses.
pros: Amazing training facilities, standard expectation to not break regulations and work ethically
cons:
Just undergone massive restructures and removed a lot of support staff leaving field staff to carry a heavier load. Poor work/life balance, pay less than the rest of the industry but very high expectations for call rates and after hours work, annual leave constraints and travel out of work hours. I was working 50-60 hour weeks and this still wasnt enough.
A lot of politics in management and it seemed people were promoted and rewarded based on their links not skill. Upper management would often contradict important statements they had made.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Very good drug pipeline, and  track record of bringing molecules to the clinic
cons: Work life balance could be better.

headline: Looking to leave
pros: A wide offering of developmental programs
cons: Unfair practices when it comes to promotions.

headline: Business Analyst
pros:
I am proud to say that I worked at Pfizer for more than 3 years

Solid Pharma company with a good reputation. At the time we had a robust pipeline and were preparing to launch several new products that we developed- not bought like some other pharmaceutical companies.
cons: Too much comparison to other territories and areas throughout the nation- like comparing apples to oranges. It was hard to stand out with all the regulations and rules.

headline: Pfizer is a good company.
pros: Pfizer give an excellent compansation.
cons: Work Life Balance is the most difficult area working in Pfizer.

headline: Great name/rocky company
pros:
the name- recognized by everyone, like a Golden Ticket into doctor's offices
great pay and perks
cons:
Constant layoffs (nearly every year)
Constant changeover (constant change)
rocky management

headline: Great company with great vision
pros: Continuous improvement, challenging objectives, structured disciplined workflow, place to experience your competencies strongly
cons: like and dislike and unfair career opportunities

headline: Worst experience ever!
pros: Free Pfizer drugs, ability to commiserate with other inmates.
cons:
Pfizer got rid of most of its administrative staff  so that the execs could keep their jobs and hefty salaries.  In return, they all agreed to become administratively independent.  Unfortunately the execs still believe that the one and only team assistant is their personal assistant and require instant responses to their demands even though the one and only assistant is receiving similar demands from 20 other people.  They try to get their demands met instantly through chastisement and badgering, which is a sub-optimal management style.  If the one and only assistant pushes back, s/he is maligned.  

 Believing that the company can function properly without adequate administrative staff is misguided.  There are too many bad business practices to track here, so I won't get into the sadistic systems.  Suffice it to say that Pfizer has become the Walmart of the pharmaceutical industry.  Administrative candidates and AstraZeneca beware!

headline: You will grow professionally with this company and is always on the competitive edge
pros:
Pfizer offers a great compensation package and lots of training to hone a person to be on top of his game.
Everybody treats each other with respect
cons: Work life balance is sometimes compromised because of the workload of activities.

headline: Average. At least they got rid of the last CEO and got a real one. Good move!
pros: Until 7-8 years ago I would have said security. Can't go with that answer any longer with this company or this industry. Now, I'll say the freedom as a territory sales rep and the pay/benefits.
cons: Like many companies, Pfizer has a habit of often promoting "superstar" salespeople into manager/leader roles when they often don't seem to have the appropriate skill set for their new position. Really can be a problem that stunts productivity in many ways.

headline: Great benefits during hard times
pros: Pfizer offers great benefits and if you play the office politics game well you can easily find another job within the company when lay offs come. Great work/life balance.
cons: Not very challenging position and no job growth for support staff. But they pay better then most companies so you're kind of stuck.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Very dynamic company, options for advancement
cons: Sometimes overburdened with work especially around POA

headline: Pharmaceutical Sales
pros: Pay was good, nice increases at milestones, lots of training and good employees.
cons: Industry is challenging to work in creating a demotivating work environment. No opportunities for advancement, too many managers.

headline: Excellent employer, would work for them again.
pros: Scheduling of shifts, experience with new technology, excellent working environment.
cons: There were none that I experienced.

headline: Change Fatigue
pros: Different opportunities across functions and geographies
cons: Too much change in last five years, resulting in inability to optimize business

headline: Develop People
pros: Innovative products, with great benefits
cons: Bottom dollar driven company, cold at times.

headline: Lots of Politics
pros: Lots of change, opportunity to learn
cons: Watch you back, if you are open and trusting it may come back to haunt you.

headline: Good company to work!!
pros: Big company with a lot of opportunities.
cons: Company didn't trust in local people to cover high positions.

headline: A horrible experience
pros: None. terrible environment where no one cares
cons: Bunch of backstabbers that do anything to get ahead

headline: Benificial.
pros: professional environment and excellent training.
cons: To keep your success momentum.

headline: Good place to work for personal development, if you take initiative to seek out development opportunities.
pros: Good access to resources and training.  Good recognition for doing exceptional work.  Great opportunities to advance into other roles.  Mostly great working relationships with colleagues who are very capable.
cons: Bureaucracy expected of a large corporation.

headline: supply chain planner
pros: top company in pharma and good opportunities
cons: compensation is not the best in industry

headline: BIG Pharma
pros: Talent, resources and most importantly, the products, to make the work meaningful, rewarding and challenging. Pfizer does offer significant development training opportunities, for those with ambition to secure and pursue. We typically always have a seat at the table for important negotiations with customers. Great leadership for the most part.
cons: It may be a harsh truth, but people are disposable. Pfizer tends to take this to a point where we are just numbers and not people. Certainly not family. Truly caring for your people is a way to improve the culture to a point where everyone WANTS to work harder, do more and succeed. This is most evident in our R&D group, but even Sales and Marketing. Years of layoffs and restructures have taken a toll.

headline: Not bad, but quite a lot of work for the pay
pros: You definitely get to learn a lot and build valuable relationships
cons: Pay is not commensurate to work

headline: Good company, Good training
pros: training is intense but well worth it
cons: depending on the district manager you get it can be a great or terrible experience

headline: Politics, continues org changes but great experience
pros: Smart people, great culture, innovative, focus on excellence and great opportunities to learn and grow your career
cons: Politics, on-going org restructures distracting people and adjusting plans over and over

headline: Brilliant People, Corporate Culture Lacking
pros: I worked with the smartest people at Pfizer.  They do a great job of recruiting and hiring the best.  Great benefits as well.
cons: The corporate culture is extremely silo-ed.  You can give your input and opinion, but don't expect it to be considered unless you are VP and above (I was a director).  Don't expect to make friends here.  It's heads down, closed doors work.  When I left, the internal company slogan was "OWN IT," and I kid you not when I say that the N in Own It literally stood for "No jerks."  Needless to say, there are a lot of jerks.

headline: Quality Control Manager
pros: Great opportunities to develop and learn other parts of the business. They don't pigeon hole employees and if you show potential then they will help you to progress. Culture was based on teamwork and meeting common goal rather than silo's.
cons: Not much money available for external based training. Training was based on throwing in the deep end rather than official training programmes. This however suited my preference of learning.

headline: Blah So so
pros: Training ground for entry level associates
cons: Culture is still horrible and middle management still has that 'fear' mentality instilled. Ian Read tries to change the culture but reaching middle management has to be the key with employee facing initiatives to instill a more innovative core. It is still VERY VERY hierarchical..

headline: Great People and a Best in Class Atmosphere
pros: Very proactive and cutting edge strategic approach.  By far best in class in the LS industry.  In general 15-20 ahead of competition with respect to market intelligence, insights and strategic use of information.
cons: Fluctuating product line gave way to self preservation and spirit of a once close knit organization.  It will be interesting to see how the organization emerges from the turbulence of the last decade.  Seems there are better leaders in place, seasoned with good vision.

headline: Lots of change and challenge
pros: It's always changing which means you're always learning. If you have a good team, then you will have a hood support system to help with all the transitions .
cons: Lots of bureaucracy. It's a big organization, so trying to get things done can take a long time. The process tests your patience.

headline: Great environment to work
pros: Top talent, great colleagues, flexible schedule
cons: May not value employees.

headline: good company to work for
pros: they have a great benefits
cons: the are constantly laying  offs

headline: Good place to work
pros: Great company to develop your skills.  You get to do challenging work.
cons: Very bottom line focused.  Losing some talent to growing competitors

headline: Great place to work!!
pros: Really enjoyed working there. Great place to be challenged every day and learn something new. Discovering new products to help people is always the focus
cons: The commute was a pain in the neck, but unfortunately that is not something the company can help with..

headline: I learned a lot on how to navigate through corporate America (especially what not to do at my next job!)
pros: The benefits were very good. The pension, 401K matching, and healthcare. Compared with many other companies that I have seen, Pfizer has offered some of the better benefits.
cons: The people made it a miserable experience. It was hard to work in such a negative environment. Company politics made it very hard to make any career progress. It was not a question of what amount of work you actually did, but who you could cozy up to. Burn out rate was very high. Senior management truly accessible to only a few.

headline: great
pros: the experience was a great one
cons: nothing negative about the company

headline: Great place to get practical pharmaceutical experience
pros: Fantastic local management who care.
cons: Dealing with the every 2 year lay offs.

headline: Getting smaller and smaller
pros: How they help people....that part is good
cons: company will keep getting smaller for a while due to the industry

headline: Finance Department in Egypt
pros:
- Colleagues are very friendly and helpful. 
- The work load is fair and you learn lots of accounting. 
- The finance director and controller are professional and friendly! (Something that's hard to find nowadays in other companies)  
- Responsible for other Middle East countries. 
- Job rotation within the department.
cons: It's hard to get a promotion in the finance department. Very limited hierarchy.

headline: Global Leader
pros: Very competitive salary and benefits.  Talented co-workers.  Large corporation with global footprint.
cons: Substantial lay-offs since 2010, offshoring, reorganizations and acquisitions created competitive internal environment.   Little development opportunities as available in prior block buster years.  More focus on bottom-line and higher salary could impact cost cutting.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good learning experience.  Great training program. A lot of committees to participate in.
cons: Another restructuring and laying off. Opportunity to move up not always available as quickly as would like.

headline: Over worked, under paid, low moral.
pros: The stock compensation plan is good and the price seems to be moving in the right direction.

headline: Constant Layoffs with Lots of employee turnover...not much gets done.
pros:
Pros ‚Äì - good benefit and compensation
- very little workload and very little work being done
- onsite gym and flexible working hours
- helping your manager renovating his house will get you a long way
cons:
Cons ‚Äì - all politics and no reward for hard work
- be careful with the HR. They could lure you back from cancer treatment and lay you off
- limited career growth for minorities and women in general
- severance package getting worse over the years

headline: Great learning experience
pros: Careeer Development opportunities exist here
cons: too much focus on Wall Street Numbers and cutting expenses to make up for lost revenue

headline: Great exposure, however rapidly changing work environment
pros: Smart, highly motivated, super diverse background of colleagues - possibly only rivaled by the UN building next door. Incredible global reach and scale - significant growth opportunities
cons: Tough operating environment due to lack of growth in revenues, multiple re-orgs in the past 18 months

headline: solid pharmaceutical company but beware of frequent layoffs
pros: lots of development opportunities, terrific benefits, good work-life balance, good people to work with; compensation adequate; good pipeline
cons: good ole boy network very much alive; lots of changes happen that appear just for the sake of change; frequent layoffs and reorgs,.

headline: Great
pros: Best training in the industry
cons: Upsized way too much. Grew too fast in the 2000's.

headline: A great experience that declined over the last several years
pros: Pfizer offers great benefits and fairly competitive salaries.  The work that they are doing is really important and it is very satisfying to be engaged in a company that is working to improve people's health & lives.  During my tenure with the company I worked with many intelligent and dedicated people.  The environment in Groton is much better than the corporate office in NYC.  Pfizer also is sensitive to life / work balance.
cons: Over the last several years, due to a failing and unpredictable pipeline, the company has become a lot more risk adverse and nervous.  As a result many of the decisions that the company has made are more driven based on the amount of the return rather than doing what is right for the patient.  Specifically, Pfizer is less likely to do research in diseases / conditions that will not guarantee a return of at least >/= $1 billion annually.  As a result, I found a lot of the research to be more "reegineering" established products than conducting innovative research.  Additionally the culture has become a lot more competitive than collaborative; colleagues are more likely to try to take credit for work that they may have not done completely individually themselves.  Pfizer used to be a data driven company, now it is a company driven by relationships...it's not what you know but who you know.  Many strong executives and middle managers have left the company in recent years...be careful.

The work that they are doing is really important and it is very satisfying to be engaged in a company that is working to improve people's health & lives. headline: Good, but be vigilant
pros: Good salaries and objective opportunities for promotion; employee focus when things are going well and very understanding.
cons: Politics, careerism, risk of the patent cliffs and personal pipedreams being pursued to team and site demise

headline: Would recommend
pros: My experience is in the consumer division of Pfizer.  Great co-workers, nice culture with the typical ups and downs of any large company
cons: Some leadership are difficult to work with and don't appreciate their subordinates.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: top-notch people, great training, wonderful benefits
cons: The company is always reorganizing and job security is moderate

headline: Overall a good employer.
pros: Good benefits, good culture, good opportunities.
cons: Some managers aren't good, selfish.

headline: Who's on First?
pros: Good brand, good HQ location in midtown Manhattan, open to flexible work arrangements
cons:
The company is a big, ever changing mess.  Constant turnover at leadership levels, either due to restructuring, layoffs or people leaving makes it very difficult to get traction, either on projects or in professional growth.  Just when I felt I had established a rapport with a manager I got a new one and had to start over.  

Zero emphasis on people development; this is not a culture of managing down, the people who advance are the ones who focus on managing up, even if they ignore their direct reports.

If can be almost comical how much time leaders spend jockeying for position against each other  rather than collaborating on goals that increase value.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Great compensation & Benefits. Flexible work place
cons: Too many merges and reorganizations

headline: Management team is terrible!
pros: Food, transportation covered, co-workers are friendly, free products
cons: Too much focus on sales, promotion of title but no increase in salary, some managers are useless but they are never reprimanded by their lack of work.

headline: Excellent!
pros: Great pay, great opportunities, good size territories
cons: None really, it's a great company

headline: Great Company & People
pros: The training is phenomenal and the people are smart and energetic. The compensation, healthcare and other benefits (such as paid maternity/paternity leave) are best in the industry.
cons: The job became a little monotonous after a few years. Also, the company went through several major layoffs, which shook the morale of the remaining employees.

headline: I worked with some really great people at Pfizer.
pros: They pay very well, and allow for a great deal of autonomy.  This may be because no one knows what anyone else is doing.
cons: Everyone is dispensable.  They buy up smaller compainies, digest them and spit out.

headline: Encouraged and supported career development
pros: Large organisation with many opportunities to grow.
cons: Unrelenting pressure to constantly improve efficiencies - you can only improve so much before you start to have a negative impact on the organisation.

headline: Plenty to learn, not nearly enough pay, must follow a detailed track for career advancement with no wiggle room.
pros: Manager was great, work could be as challenging as you desire, don't have to worry about budget or lab supplies. I enjoyed my time there immensely despite having many concerns, my coworkers were fantastic and my team was great. My manager invested a lot of time in me but there were still many shortcomings. A good place to be if you have all of the credentials, but you're still a cog in a large wheel.
cons: The above mentioned is all that was good at Pfizer and although I enjoyed my time there, it still fell short of expectations. As one of the biggest pharma companies, you'd expect pay to be equal to or above other companies, but they definitely were not. The group I was in, played an extremely vital role in many projects, was constantly asked to go above and beyond job descriptions, and were always being told how vital we were to the success of our site. However, when it came to compensation, yearly reviews, and pay raises we were ALWAYS told that a 1-3 percent raise was standard across Pfizer and that it was out of our direct manager's hands. Inflation is 3% and my raise was 1.9%. I'm getting paid less this year than last?!

headline: Lucrative, but frustrating
pros: Ability to make at or above industry norm in salary. Good to be associated with the largest pharmaceutical company in the world
cons: The company is so big that it is difficult to advance - too many people for every job opening, and not many openings to begin with. Arrogance from NYC senior management is ridiculous. Also, there is a ton of duplicity in departments and very little focus on communication across groups.

headline: Manager and representative
pros: Excellent first in class products
cons: To much focus on structure.

headline: Great place to work
pros: I love the work I get to do.  Very rewarding.  The people are great.  Trustworthy leadership.  People are treated with respect.
cons: It is a big organization.  So it can be difficult to move as quickly as you'd like sometimes.  There are multiple layers of decision making required.  But that's nature of almost any large company.  And the extra layers does offer additional compliance checks so it's necessarily a bad thing

headline: director

headline: fantastic organization

headline: Great Company

headline: Big company, lots of opportunity if you are change agile

headline: I worked for Pfizer 18+ years in various  sales and sales management capacities, and participated in 21 product launchs
pros: During the days of blockbuster medications and huge profits, innovation and initiative were celebrated and rewarded. I worked with some of the finest managers who were gifted leaders and found a way to tap into each individuals strengths. Their focus was positive development and continuous improvement.  You never needed to to 'keep your head down', but rather your opinion was required and expected. Having worked in a healthy work culture, you can recognize it anywhere, and also become quickly aware when the culture is not aligned with the stated business goals.
cons: Respect for people became  a lost core value. Leaders left Pfizer and were replaced by management governed by greed and desperate, dishonest yes men.

headline: High pressure, good benefits, good people
pros: The majority of the people are smart, good at what they do, and nice/helpful. The work is interesting and cutting edge and hard work is recognized
cons: The work is fast-paced and high pressure. People are competitive and there are politics.

headline: My experience with Pfizer has mostly been positive.  It's a good place to work as long as you have good drugs to sell.
pros: Huge company, lots of resources and benefits.  Job security while patents are in place.  Lots of really good people all trying hard to do a good job.

Positions are eliminated when people move on to other positions which makes advancement much more difficult in the current environment.
